sect1.title: Configure Log-File Parsers
sect1.para: &logtracker; can read and interpret log files of almost any formats, as long as an appropriate parser configuration is provided. Parser configurations are maintained on the parser configuration tab within the global Configuration Dialog Box. It can be opened by

sect1.para: Parser configuration heavily depends on Regular Expression Processing. &logtracker; uses Java's regular expression implementation. All processing is done on a per line basis. Regex capturing groups are used to identify and extract relevant portions of the log file lines.
A sample parser configuration tab is shown in
The controls in this dialog are:

listitem.para: Lists all available Parser configurations. The first three configurations in the list (which are grayed out) are standard configurations, which can not be edited by the user. They can be used for standard situations or as sample configurations for your own configurations.
Choose one of the configurations and its configuration parameters are shown in the lower half of the configuration box.
The name of a parser can be edited by double clicking its in in the Parser Config column of the table.
is used to define the basic type of the log file (see ). The type can only be modified when a configuration just has been created by using the new-Button.
These fields can be used to specifiy which lines within the log file should be considered or ignored. Lines "containing" or "matching" a specific regex-Pattern may be included or excluded.

Line inclusion works slightly different, depending on the log file type. When using a Service Call Statistics configuration, ignores lines are indeed completely ignored. When using "Message Logs" or "Correlation Logs", included lines serve as markers of the beginning of a next log file entry.

The Extraction Pattern must match all complete "included" lines. It defines capturing groups which contain the information that needs to be extracted from the log file line. The required information depends on the log file type.

The sample log line is not a part of the configuration but just a small utility which supports authoring correct regular expressions. Enter a sample log line and the effect of the extraction pattern is visualized by highlighting text portions in the sample log line. The matched text is highlighted in yellow. Capturing groups are highlighted in green.

Defined which capturing group (identified by its positional number) contains which part of the information, and how this information must be extracted. The available capturing group parameters depend on the file type. All possible values are shown in .
Load From File loads Log Parser Configurations from a log tracker configuration file.
Save to File saves the marked Log Parser Configurations into a log tracker configuration file. Use Ctrl-Click or Shift-Click to select more than one Log Parser Configuration.

Create New creates a new, empty Log Parser Configuration.
It is often easier, to select, copy and modify an already existing configuration.
Copy creates a copy of the selected Log Parser configuration.
Delete the selected Log Parser Configuration.
OK applies all edits that were made in the Log Parser Configuration Dialog.
Cancel discards all edits that were made within the Log Parser Configuration Dialog.

entry.para: The capturing group with this number contains a time stamp, which represents the occurrence time of the logged event. (It might represent the time, when the information was logged.)
The Time Format String is used to specify the format of the time stamp. The format is defined as a Java SimpleDateFormat pattern.
The Language field is relevant, if the time stamps use a text form for month names.
The TimeZone field specifies the time zone of the time stamps in the log file. If specified, all time stamps will be converted to the user's local time.
The capturing group with this number contains a correlation id. The correlation id is used to correlate messages from different log files. See .
The capturing group with this number contains a name that specifies the service that was called.
Services that should not be considered in the statistics can be excluded by specifying its names in the Exclude Services field. Service names must be comma separated.
The capturing group with this number contains the the lapse time that was used by the service execution
The floating point number that is found within this group is multiplied by the conversion factor. The resulting lapse time should be measured in seconds.
The capturing group with this number contains a name of the user of the service call.

The capturing group with this number contains a return of the service call. The return code is compared with the value within Value representing "OK". If it is equal, the service call is considered as successful, otherwise as failed. (Successful service calls are represented by a dot within the service call scatter plot, unsuccessful calls are represented by a cross sign.)

When checked, the relevant occurrence time is calculated as occurrence time minus execution time. In some log files, the log entry is written, when the service ends. The user, however, might want to base the service statistics on the the service start times. This options can be used for that purpose.
The capturing group with this number contains a keyword that specifies the severity of the message. Typical entries are ERROR, WARNING, INFO, etc.
The capturing group with this number contains a free format message text.
The encoding of the log file. Typical values are UTF-8, or ISO-8859-1.
